Quantum theory is a highly successful and elegant way of describing the physical world. However, it is not a theory in the ordinary sense of the word, in that it is not based on a classical foundation. This has led to a number of attempts to provide such a foundation, and to prove that the resulting theories are equivalent to quantum theory. The most promising of these attempts is the reconstruction program, which has led to a number of different foundations. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. The Myxozoa are thought to have evolved from a free-living ancestor that parasitizes cnidarians, and thus the study of the Myxozoa can provide insights into the evolution of parasitism. Here, we present a genomic analysis of two myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarians. We also show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported animal genomes, and that it is reduced in gene content. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in gene content. The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s food supply is threatened by climate change. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, but the impact of temperature variability on yield is not well understood. Here, we show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries as the global mean temperature increases. This variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in diet, but that even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location had different diets. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammal species may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of species-level identification in understanding the mechanisms that maintain biodiversity. (Less)

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. We also assess the effects of the CARES Act loans relative to grants.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective nature of the sinks removing plastic debris from the surface of the open ocean. The fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The age of the Solar System is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The age of the Solar System is also one of the most important questions in astrobiology. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This suggests that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to offspring correlates with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the amount of resources provided to offspring rather than an increase in the number of offspring produced. This suggests that the limiting factor in reproduction is metabolic power rather than resource availability.

The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling blood pressure, and controlling inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control its function by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network of cells that is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The endothelium is able to rapidly and efficiently integrate information from multiple sources to control its function. This communication system is important for the control of cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and open data has never been greater. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to a wide range of users.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. The activation gate closes before the selectivity filter opens, and this allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that a Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position is able to invert the allosteric coupling and to induce a lack of C-type inactivation gating. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the KcsA mutant. This knowledge will be useful for the design of new potassium channel modulators.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be shaped by the presence of a diverse set of microorganisms. In this study, we show that anaerobic gut fungi, which are thought to be rare members of the gut microbiome, synthesize a diverse set of natural products. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This study also highlights the potential of anaerobic fungi as a source of natural products for drug discovery.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identifies an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, which is associated with decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production and reduced social competitiveness. These findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors is a critical issue in the field of mechanical engineering. In this work, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized and then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design mechanical devices with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we investigated the role of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the heterochronic regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 is expressed at high levels and is required for the developmental silencing of adult hemoglobin expression. The results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a key player in the heterochronic regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for the development of hemoglobin disorders in humans. The results also suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobin disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. We found that mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, highly frequent in cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance, and that this resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the transcriptional regulation of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). This mechanism of resistance can be overcome by targeting mTORC1 with rapalogs and ferroptosis with the lipid peroxidase erastin, and this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings provide a potential therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with an increased risk of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy failed to reverse the decline of birds associated with early-seral forests. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy on biodiversity. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to other targets. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of such technology use on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth system. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and that the YDB spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results provide evidence that the YDB cooling was triggered by an impact.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial, and its function in the periphery and in the central tolerance of T cells has not been fully elucidated. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, and that its function in the periphery is more important than previously thought. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency in adult mice can be used to study the development of autoimmunity in a disease model that is not fatal.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of beetles and the factors that have driven their diversification remain poorly understood. We used a combination of molecular phylogenetics and the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls to trace the evolution of beetles and to understand the factors that have driven their diversification. We found that the evolution of beetles is driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the relationship between population size and CCE may be nonlinear. Finally, they highlight the importance of the working memory in the process of cultural transmission. This work is important for evolutionary psychology, technology, and the design of human-technology interaction.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is also a strong predictor of AD risk. APOE is also a major protein in the brain, where it is produced by astrocytes. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a rationale for the use of APOE-targeted therapies in AD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation is still a mystery. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of iron crystallization is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of iron is more likely to be driven by the bcc phase than by the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of chronic marijuana use are unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also show increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might be a key mechanism in the development of marijuana abuse and addiction.

Language is the most complex form of communication, and the human brain is the only known organ that can process it. However, the brain’s language machinery is not known, limiting our understanding of how we think and communicate. Here, we show that artificial neural networks, a form of “brain-inspired” computation, can predict neural responses to sentences in the human brain in a way that is correlated with how well the networks predict whether the next word in a sentence will appear or not on a subsequent sentence reading task. These results provide computational evidence that the brain’s mechanisms for processing language are predictive in nature. They also suggest that the brain may use neural representations that are highly predictive of the next word in a sentence, and that these representations may be important for language comprehension.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many deep learning algorithms are unstable in the sense of numerical analysis. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable in the sense of numerical analysis, and we prove that they can be used to solve inverse problems in science and engineering. We believe that this work will have a major impact on the field of deep learning, and we hope that it will lead to the development of more stable deep learning algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past epidemics. This is a dangerous misconception. The classic experiment used in this argument is a flawed study that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 years. It is a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research. It is also a reminder that, in the face of a pandemic, the most important thing is to get the science right.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and its history is intertwined with the development of modern medicine. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a Mexican patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the well-studied Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably conserved, despite their ancient separation, and that they are both neuropathogenic. These findings have implications for the study of leprosy and its treatment, as well as for the study of the evolution of pathogenic bacteria. (PsycINFO Database Record

The dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question of fundamental physics. It is also of great relevance for quantum technologies, as it determines the lifetime of quantum memories and the speed of quantum gates. However, a complete understanding of the dynamics of entanglement is still lacking for interacting systems. Here, we show that the integrability of the model allows for a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the scaling limit of infinite system size and large times. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical data. Our work thus provides a solid foundation for the study of the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by the pharmaceutical company Pfizer and its partner BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which is a major barrier to mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. This vaccine is highly attenuated, has a short incubation period, and is protective in a relevant hamster model. The vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C, which is a major advantage over the currently available vaccine. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. This suggests that human ectoparasites were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results also suggest that the Black Death was not a single epidemic, but rather the start of a series of outbreaks. This highlights the importance of human ectoparasites as vectors of disease and the need for further research on the history of plague transmission.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also highlights the importance of using TRAP1-null cells in the study of TRAP1 function. (Read more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is known to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we show that the action of ADF is enhanced by mechanical stress. We propose that this enhancement is due to a torque that is induced by the mechanical stress. This torque is generated by the connection of filaments, and is enhanced by the twist of filaments. We propose that this torque is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filaments. Our results have implications for understanding the role of mechanical stress in ADF-mediated regulation of the actin cytoskeleton. They also have implications for understanding the role of twist in the action of other molecular motors.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food and beverage industry. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior and for developing strategies to reduce the consumption of high-calorie foods. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west, and from the highlands to the coast. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic growth happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of African ancestry from males than from females. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and to improve the knowledge of the human colonization of the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that the influence of others’ positive experiences is positive for people. These results suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ negative experiences can be negative for people, and that the use of social media can be used to reduce negative emotions. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms and for our understanding of the influence of others on our emotions. They also suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical component of this process, and many modifications can alter mRNA structure and function. In this study, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of a modification can alter the rate of protein synthesis in a cell. These findings have implications for how mRNA modifications can alter the rate of protein synthesis and the rate of protein production in cells. Our results also suggest that the ribosome can encounter modifications in the mRNA sequence and alter the rate of translation. This study provides a better understanding of how mRNA modifications can alter the rate of protein synthesis in cells. (Less)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the feeling of worth is associated with positive changes in outcomes over a 4-y period. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology, but the mechanisms driving the evolution of aquatic mammals are poorly understood. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results suggest that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of a size attractor in aquatic mammals. This work provides a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and other organisms that inhabit different physical environments.

The common cold is one of the most common and most economically costly diseases in the world. The virus that causes the vast majority of colds, rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. In this study, we show that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are involved in sensing the environment, and in particular, the surface of a solid object. This surface sensing is mechanosensitive, and is used by the bacteria to regulate the expression of genes involved in virulence and biofilm formation. Our results thus demonstrate that type IV pili are not only involved in twitching motility, but also in sensing the surface of a solid object. This is an important finding, as it shows that type IV pili are involved in sensing the environment, and in particular, the surface of a solid object.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly increasing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is of great importance for the future of agriculture and the environment. We show that the use of pesticides is not limited to the use of the most harmless ones, but that the most toxic pesticides are used in large quantities. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in humans and animals is a major concern, and the role of animals in the transmission of the virus is a matter of great debate. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer in the United States. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings highlight the need for a more comprehensive approach to the study of animal reservoirs of SARS-CoV-2. (Less)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a growing need for a better understanding of the disease process. Here, we report the identification of a neuron-specific inflammatory response in the brains of AD patients and AD transgenic animals. We show that this response is not triggered by soluble Aβ, but rather by soluble Aβ-burdened neurons. This finding is significant because it suggests that the accumulation of soluble Aβ species may be a more direct cause of AD pathology than previously thought. Our results may also have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies that target the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ. Finally, we propose that the identification of a neuron-specific inflammatory response may be of use in the development of diagnostic biomarkers and therapeutic targets for AD. The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in human history, as it allowed the production of a protein source that was not available in the wild. The earliest evidence for the domestication of chickens comes from the Near East, where the species was first domesticated. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. Here we present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread at that site, and that the species was already being used for economic purposes in the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high resolution. We have applied this method to maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied for many years, and have found that the folding of this protein is more complex than previously thought.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping Np4-capped RNAs, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine deprivation is a common mechanism involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis and that citrulline administration can be used as a therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and proliferation. Our results suggest that arginine deprivation is a common mechanism involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis and that citrulline administration can be used as a therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and proliferation. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is key for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves at a critical rate, which is independent of the rate at which it is observed. The term “critical rate” is used in the sense of the theory of dynamical systems, which is a branch of mathematics. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly through strain engineering, which opens up opportunities to control its properties. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is even more so, as there are no known antifungal peptides that are currently used in agriculture. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, the 36-residue NCR044, and show that it is highly active against plant fungal pathogens. We also show that it is able to bind to fungal cell membranes and that it is able to induce reactive oxygen species, which are known to be involved in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a model system for understanding the molecular mechanisms of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall. The protein is stored in blood cells and released upon injury. The protein has two domains, A1 and B3, that bind to platelets and to the endothelial cell surface, respectively. We show that force application to the protein switches the two domains to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating the binding reaction. The results explain the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of platelet adhesion, and suggest that the mechanism can be used to treat the disorder. The results also suggest that the mechanism can be used to study the regulation of other proteins. The results are important for understanding the regulation of the protein in health and disease. The results are also important for understanding the regulation of other proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. In recent years, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has become a major focus of research, but the number of studies is still limited. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. The database is based on a large number of publicly available metagenomic datasets, which are analyzed to identify viruses associated with humans. The database contains information on the location of the virus in the genome, as well as the sequence of the viral protein. The database can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health, as well as to identify new viruses that may be associated with human diseases.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability is inadequate. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred to be linked to the temperature history of the oceans, which in turn is linked to the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface is also linked to the temperature of the atmosphere, which in turn is linked to the evolution of the atmosphere. Thus, the temperature history of the surface is linked to the evolution of life in a complex and interconnected manner. This study provides a new method for reconstructing the temperature history of the surface of the Earth, and thus the evolution of life, by using the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. The results of this study provide evidence for a cooling of the surface of the Earth over geological time, which is consistent with other methods of temperature reconstruction. This study demonstrates the value of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insights into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Less)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2019. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting that it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work also highlights the potential for the use of RBC biophysical properties as a diagnostic tool for malaria. (Less)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease outcome in the context of low humidity. They also suggest that humidity may be a potential target for the development of influenza vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Formal model comparison indicated that the model of multiword phrase construction provided a better fit than probability-based models at most sites in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices. Activity in those regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in a wide range of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers a tissue-specific response to the two forms of Axin, which is important for the proper functioning of the Wnt pathway. This study provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of redundant genes and their roles in the development of the organism.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and this behavior is attenuated by lesions of the dopamine system. Here we show that this stimulation-induced eating is mediated by a circuit involving the LH and ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), and that lesions of this circuit prevent the eating response. We also show that stimulation of the LH causes animals to eat when the animals are deprived of food, suggesting that this circuit is involved in the regulation of feeding in the absence of food. Finally, we show that stimulation of the LH causes animals to eat when the animals are satiated, suggesting that this circuit is involved in the regulation of satiety. These results provide a more complete characterization of the brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is of great importance to agriculture. However, the efficiency of this process is limited by the low abundance of N2-fixing bacteria in the soil. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to engineer nitrogen-fixing symbioses in agriculture to improve the efficiency of N2-fixation and to reduce the risk of N2-fixing bacteria spreading to nonhost plants. We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an auditory organ that is not part of its body but is instead part of its web. The web is made of protein and is self-manufactured by the spider. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect the sound-induced air particle movements, which are more sensitive than the acoustic responsivity of the spider’s eardrum. The spider can adjust the size of its web to meet its needs, and it can regenerate the web to repair damage. This study provides a unique model for studying the outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in animals. It also provides a new way to design acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health and the economy. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic, but the cost of these vaccines is a major barrier to their global access. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for inclusion in a vaccine. This variant is easy to express in bacteria, has high affinity for ACE2, and can be presented on a virus-like particle. This variant may be a cost-effective addition to a vaccine to improve its efficacy against variants of concern. This work provides a potential solution to the global access problem of vaccines.

The role of ALK in the development of human cancer has been established by the discovery of ALK mutations in neuroblastoma. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK) signaling is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish lateral line. We further show that zebrafish ALK/LTK signaling is activated by secreted ALKAL proteins. Our results provide evidence that ALK/LTK signaling is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study also provides a model for studying ALK/LTK signaling in vivo. Finally, our results suggest that secreted ALKAL proteins are potential ligands for ALK/LTK. This study provides a model for studying ALK/LTK signaling in vivo. It also suggests that secreted ALKAL proteins are potential ligands for ALK/LTK. (PsycINFO Database Record

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The study of ancient plague genomes can provide insights into the origins of the disease and its adaptation to its new host. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which allowed us to explore the diversity of the disease during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that the disease was not a recent arrival in Eurasia and that it spread rapidly across continents, accompanied by a stepwise evolution of the pathogen. These data provide a unique perspective on the formative years of plague and its adaptation to its new host. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (i.e., hegemonic masculinity) and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and for Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of masculinity as a cultural ideology. (PsycINFO Database Record

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural systems is a major concern for the climate and the environment. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to intensive crop production has released massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices can mitigate this trend and that the management of perennial pastures can be a powerful tool for increasing soil C storage. Our results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans and the development of strategies to mitigate that risk. We present a framework for identifying and prioritizing wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We also present a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to prioritize their own research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a chemical basis for the red color of nectar, which is a key trait that attracts pollinators. (Less)

We present the first genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from the Early Middle Ages in Europe. The results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Middle Ages may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The emergence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) has caused a global public health concern. The virus is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how these bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the cross-species transmission of MERS-CoV and other bat coronaviruses. They also provide a reference for the development of MERS-CoV vaccines and antiviral drugs. This article

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, with dengue virus as the most abundant pathogen. We also identified underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV. These findings highlight the importance of ongoing pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, and the need for rapid public health response. This study also demonstrates the feasibility of using a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in other resource-scarce settings and in other parts of the world. (Less)

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, there are also significant differences that have led to the evolution of new mechanisms. One of the most important differences is the role of the PCNA sliding clamp, which is essential for the replication of the lagging strand in humans but not in S. cerevisiae. In humans, the PCNA clamp is essential for the initiation of replication but is dispensable for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. We show here that the PCNA clamp is also essential for the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. This has important implications for the replication of the lagging strand in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, and in this paper we show that RNA molecules can also be evolved to have polymerase activity. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world and the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of a neighborhood in determining its future physical appearance.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the treatment of tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new therapeutic strategy for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a metal that can be toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of metal-binding metabolites is well established, but the role of these metabolites in copper homeostasis and in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes is not. Here we report the discovery of a copper-binding isocyanide biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus, and demonstrate that the cluster is expressed in vivo and has a role in copper homeostasis and in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. This study demonstrates the existence of a previously unknown role for fungal natural products in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. This knowledge is important for understanding the mechanisms by which fungi regulate interactions with microbes in the environment and in the human body. (PsycINFO Database Record

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, is a unique feature of the sedimentary record of the ancient Lake Gale environment. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at the base of the sedimentary sequence at the base of the Lake Gale sequence is a strong indication that the ancient lake was a source of silica for the formation of the tridymite. The presence of tridymite in the ancient lake environment is a strong indication that the ancient lake was a source of silica for the formation of the tridymite.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is already affecting the performance of forests. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. We found that Th17 cells, which are known to express the transcription factor T-bet, are able to induce colitis in mice. However, when we blocked T-bet expression, they were unable to induce colitis. These results indicate that T-bet is important for the development of Th17 cells and for the induction of colitis. Moreover, we found that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Further studies are needed to determine the extent to which these findings are relevant to human inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disorder with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the key cells for voluntary muscle contraction. The disease is progressive, and death is due to respiratory failure. The disease is heterogeneous, and the cause of death is not known. We report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced astrocytes, which are toxic to motor neurons. This method now enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will help us to understand the disease mechanism and develop therapeutics. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. The role of the microbiome in vector competence for infectious agents is a topic of great interest. Here, we show that the human granulocytic anaplasmosis agent, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the microbiota of the vector, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the agent induces the vector to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of vector control strategies for vector-borne diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the last common ancestor of the tail and the origin of the pygostyle, a compound bone that is the last common ancestor of the tail. The study of the evolution of the tail is important for understanding the origin of flight and the evolution of the avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and discuss the evolution of the tail in this group.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to be camouflaged. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolution of vertebrates. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most diverse group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States. Breast cancer is heterogeneous, and the ability of cancer cells to form cancer stem cells (CSCs) is a key factor in the development of metastasis and resistance to therapy. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, a demethylase that demethylates NANOG mRNA, which encodes a breast cancer stem cell factor. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways, and is required for the induction of breast CSCs by hypoxia. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Read more)

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed Bibles were produced in the 15th century. The first pocket Bibles were produced in the 13th century, and the first printed pocket Bibles were produced in the 1450s. The source of parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This study reports the results of a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. The results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is a matter of intense debate, but the timing of the event is well established only at coarse temporal resolution. Here we provide a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath, allowing a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. The results also provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is not well understood. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. These findings provide insights into the function of RORα in the intestine and suggest that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
