The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor-binding domain of ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the receptor-binding domain, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. (Read more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, which would increase the Black−White gap in life expectancy to over 5 y. These projections imply that the pandemic has exacerbated the structural inequalities that have led to the persistent underperformance of Black and Latino Americans in health and other areas of society.

The chemical behavior of matter is one of the most fundamental aspects of science. The chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, are central to the study of chemical reactions and the properties of matter. In this paper, we show that these properties change with pressure, and we provide a theoretical framework to predict and explain these changes. We also show that these properties can be used to predict the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under extreme conditions.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been a major driver of fire regimes in the past and will continue to be so in the future. However, we also find that climate change has been a major driver of fire activity in the past and will continue to be so in the future. This means that climate change may be more important in driving future fire activity than human ignitions. We also find that climate change has already warmed the world by up to 0.11 °C, and that this warming may be reversed by recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity. This highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to better understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon in the future.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts in the organ of light, and that the glycan catabolism is required for the periodic acidification of the organ that is necessary for the symbionts to produce light. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more general mechanism for regulating the health of the associated epithelium. This article is protected by copyright. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We model the structure of a corpus as a sequence of topics, where each topic is a distribution over words. We use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We also provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the structure of text data.

The Black Death, which occurred in Europe in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease was likely introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis for centuries. This suggests that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into Europe, where it established itself. Our results provide evidence for a long-term persistence of the bacterium in Asia, which is not in line with the hypothesis of a single introduction of the disease into Europe.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases to affect the sea stars of the world. The disease is caused by a densovirus that has spread rapidly throughout the affected populations. The present study provides evidence that the densovirus is the cause of the disease and that it has been present in the affected populations for at least 72 y. The results also provide a mechanism for the spread of the virus between populations. The findings have important implications for the management of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The IL1RAP (IL1R3) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west, and from the highlands to the coast. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic growth happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of African ancestry to females than to males. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and to improve the knowledge of the human history of the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the crop expert data and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed approach can be used to monitor the status of other agricultural commodities and services.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on different timescales, from milliseconds to seconds. We also show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to warming across a range of sites and biomes. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, and provide a comprehensive analysis of the response of soil respiration to warming. Our results provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. These results highlight the importance of studying soil respiration at a range of sites and biomes to improve our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The evolution of the plastid genome is a key aspect of the origin and evolution of life. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of life, and the molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolution of the plastid genome is a dynamic process that is shaped by the interplay of macroevolutionary events and molecular evolution. This model can be applied to other systems to understand the molecular signature of major evolutionary transitions.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of such a drought by a factor of five to six. This is due to a combination of the warming of the climate and the intensification of the rainfall deficit by the drying of the atmosphere. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study is important for the water resources management in SSA and for the development of adaptation strategies. It also highlights the need for a rapid reduction of greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major event in the history of science. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first sample of which was collected in 1946, is a major event in the history of science and technology. The discovery of this material, which is a new composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, is of interest to scientists and engineers because it is the oldest known example of a quasicrystal and because it is the oldest known anthropogenic material to be associated with nuclear technology.

Photosynthesis is the primary process by which life on Earth is sustained. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the capture of light by chlorophyll pigments. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one from plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria, and the other from anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria. Here we show that the two enzymes are related, and that the anoxygenic enzyme requires a new protein, which we term BciE, to function. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the cyclase reaction. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, including mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) signaling. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human-caused global warming. We also show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased, and that this increase is also due to human-caused global warming. These results highlight the importance of anthropogenic climate change for the occurrence of the acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk associated with the 2012–2014 drought.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large genetic component. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the store-operated Ca2+ release-activated Ca2+ (CRAC) channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the ORAI1 channel that result in bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy in patients with Stormorken syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In this study, we show that the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain is mediated by endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires the fusion protein 1 complex. These findings provide a model for the propagation of aggregates in the Drosophila brain and suggest that the mechanisms of spreading in Drosophila and humans may be similar. This model may also be useful for studying the mechanisms of spreading in other neurodegenerative diseases. Finally, the use of Drosophila in this study provides a platform for the development of new therapeutics.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still poorly understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential of MTX as a therapeutic target for the treatment of viral infections. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus the study of cancer metabolism is a major focus of cancer research. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) 1 and 2. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the cell is a well-established phenomenon in biology. However, the presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS is not well understood. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners of these proteins. This suggests that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, and thus a specific feature of ALS. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that lived below the surface of the water. The study of Montsechia, a plant that lived more than 120 million y ago, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at the very beginning of the evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in virology, but the evolution of the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been difficult to study. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The study also highlights the potential of ancient viral sequences to provide information about the evolution of viruses in the distant past. This article is protected by copyright. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is in agreement with the rate reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in its Fifth Assessment Report. Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of the middle class.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The application of NMR to enzyme catalysis has been limited by the lack of atomic-resolution characterization of the enzyme active site. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide such characterization, revealing the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, highlighting the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The results also provide a rationale for why indole, an isostere of the natural substrate, does not react, while L-tryptophan does. This work demonstrates the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. The data presented here support testing of remdesivir in the context of a MERS clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance in the fight against the current pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. This is an example of a strategy used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage in living cells. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions must first be cleaved by virus-producing cells to be secreted from the cell, and then must be cleaved by target-cell receptors to be able to fuse with the cell membrane. We found that the first cleavage steps are important for MERS-CoV infection, and that the second cleavage steps are important for infection into human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures. These findings suggest that the first cleavage steps are important for MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. The food choices of the population have a major influence on these outcomes, and it is therefore important to understand how to encourage healthier diets. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a large impact on sales, and that this impact is concentrated among diners who are less likely to choose vegetarian meals at baseline. These results suggest that it may be possible to make a significant contribution to population health and environmental sustainability by altering the physical environment in which people make food choices.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we apply a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes. We also find that oncogene-induced changes to the surfaceome are accompanied by changes to the glycoproteome, and that these changes are highly oncogene-specific. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Less)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The key idea is that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is because we have “cherry picked” the data, and so must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. We show how this idea can be used in practice.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of blood vessels. However, the development of ECs has been difficult to achieve, and the generation of ECs has become increasingly important for providing vascular plexus to regenerated organs, such as the liver. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In addition, we show that ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. (PsycINFO Database Record

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened a new field of research in the field of RTKs. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that the two ligands encoded by the human genome are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and the body, respectively, and that they are both activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem, and the molecular mechanisms of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are still unclear. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the main cause of seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Therefore, our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life and property, as well as a major cause of ecosystem degradation. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of a neighborhood in determining its future physical appearance.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. We further demonstrate that the ortholog of sTRP1 in Drosophila melanogaster, dTRPγ, is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and also a potential approach to control insect pests. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the time between cell infection and viral production, the rate of viral production, the time a cell spends producing virus, and the number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the development of tumors. Here, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome. The microbiome, in turn, triggers a regenerative response in the tumor, which in turn triggers the microbiome, and so on. We propose that the activity level of JNK signaling in the intestinal epithelium is a key factor in maintaining homeostasis. Our results identify a mechanism that can be used to extend the lifespan of animals. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may result in the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can repress the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The timing of the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a matter of debate. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, which occurred exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate. This finding provides a plausible explanation for the start of deglaciation and the associated changes in climate and ocean circulation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need for improved management to protect biodiversity and ensure food security. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the nervous system. This discovery is important because it provides a platform for the discovery of genes that are important for regeneration. Moreover, it suggests that the mechanisms that control regeneration in the nervous system are more similar than previously thought.

The process of recombination is central to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key parameter in population genetics. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution is similar to that in yeast and in mice. We also find that the distribution of recombination is highly correlated with the distribution of transcription, suggesting that the process of transcription may be a major driver of recombination in plants and animals.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of a small fraction of neurons is sufficient to generate the observed static signal. This activity is not random, but organized into networks that are functionally relevant. Here, we show that the resting brain can be organized into a hierarchy of metabolically distinct networks, which are topologically and functionally related. We also show that these networks are altered in Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. These results provide a framework for the study of the resting brain, and for the development of new imaging techniques that can be used to study the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for proper translation. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in yeast, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and that it is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This 5′ modification may be important for the regulation of gene expression.

We show that epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We also show that high glucose induces similar persistent hypomethylation at thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) in cultured human monocytes, a gene known to be associated with hyperglycemia and related complications. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a potential epigenetic mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

In this study, we show that the expression of the cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in breast cancer. We also show that FSIP1 is associated with poor prognosis in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) and is associated with drug resistance. Computational modeling revealed that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was confirmed by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. Finally, the results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a potential biomarker for the diagnosis and management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not well understood. Here we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of a class of nitrogenous volatiles in tobacco plants, and that the gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit and opens the door to the development of new tomato varieties with improved flavor. We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are more severe when species diversity is low. This is because diversity is more important in maintaining the thermal tolerance of species, which is the main determinant of ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for predicting the impacts of climate change on the functioning of natural systems and the services they provide.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. It is divided into superficial and deep layers, and the superficial layers are subdivided into three distinct zones, which are thought to be involved in different aspects of spatial processing. However, the anatomical and functional organization of the superficial layers is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to image the activity of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC during free-moving behavior. We found that neurons in the superficial layers are organized into three distinct zones, which are anatomically and functionally segregated. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the superficial layers of MEC and will be useful for future studies of the function of this important brain structure. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal factors. In this study, we show that the flowering of the dodder Cuscuta australis is synchronized with the flowering of its host. We demonstrate that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The precise nature of the pathology in this disorder is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here we show that the dopamine-producing neurons are connected to a unique system of neurons in the ventral midbrain, the nigral dopamine system, that is affected in the disorder. We also show that the dopamine neurons are connected to cortical regions that are thought to be involved in mood and motivation. These results suggest that the dopamine system is connected to a system of neurons in the ventral midbrain that is critical to the control of mood and motivation and that this system is affected in Parkinson’s disease. Thus, the dopamine system is likely to be involved in the regulation of mood and motivation in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN is composed of specialized cells that are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. These cells are located in the wall of the sinus node and are called sinoatrial cells (SANCs). SANCs are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat and are the natural pacemaker of the heart. SANCs are also responsible for the generation of the heartbeat by integrating signals from the heart’s electrical system with signals from the heart’s Ca2+ system. This study reveals that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study also reveals that STIM1 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. (PsycINFO Database Record

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote defense responses against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms by which Si may be used as a sustainable agricultural practice to enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, as it is in the case of other ether lipid-metabolizing enzymes. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a new model of language processing that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on different timescales, from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biotechnology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-carrying DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNAs to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that provides a wide range of goods and services to society. However, it is also a highly vulnerable area, as it is often the first to be impacted by human activities. In this study, we show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to the coastal zone, and that this source is often overlooked in current management efforts. Our findings have important implications for coastal management, as they highlight the need to consider the role of small streams in coastal eutrophication. We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a small initial condition for the universe is required to explain the observed fine-tuned properties of the universe today. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning problem may be more general than previously thought, and may be relevant to a wide range of dissipative systems.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a combination of in silico and in vivo experiments to show that NMDAR-Abs can alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. Our results also highlight the importance of the dynamic properties of the microcircuit in determining the susceptibility of the brain to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings may help to explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs encephalitis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and the potential for abrupt climate change is of great concern. In this study, we investigate a major global warming event that occurred during a glacial period, when the Earth system was already in a state of reduced greenhouse forcing. We show that the warming event was accompanied by a major perturbation of the carbon cycle, which is of relevance to our understanding of the potential for abrupt climate change today. Our results highlight the importance of considering the full range of Earth system processes when investigating abrupt climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations, but also the need for more stringent requirements to reduce deforestation in other land uses. This study also highlights the importance of monitoring and enforcement of certification requirements. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but rather a tool that can be used in combination with other policies and measures.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Less)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent and the sex of the parent’s parent. In this paper, we show that the multiple sex determination loci in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii can produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, which can be further modified by the acquisition of a new sex determination locus. These results suggest that the maintenance of multiple sex determination loci in species with multiple sexes can produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, which can be modified by the acquisition of new sex determination alleles.

The retina is challenged by a number of factors that can lead to photoreceptor cell death. One of these factors is the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. In this study, we show that Fe levels impact the retina and that Fe chelation can reduce the photodegradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of specialization is a central topic in ecology and evolution. In this study, we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is linked to the evolution of their prey. We also show that the evolution of specialization is not a dead end, but rather a process that can be linked to the evolution of other morphological traits. These findings help us understand the evolution of specialization in nature, and how it has shaped the present-day food web.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of hominin research, but the origins of the distinctive features of the hand that are shared with Neandertals are poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the origins of the distinctive human hand and its relationship to Neandertals.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus the study of cancer metabolism is a major focus of cancer research. In this study, we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target of a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits plant SHMT. We also show that this scaffold inhibits SHMT in human cells, and that this inhibition is effective in blocking colon cancer growth in mice. We further show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for colon and B-cell cancers. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This is important because, despite a growing body of literature that shows that having access to forests can improve people’s diets, there is little consideration of the role of forests in meeting nutrition goals. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a modeling approach to test causal inferences, which is rarely done in the nutrition literature. The results have implications for policy makers and researchers alike.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agriculture, allowing for the production of more food with fewer workers. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
